Matthew C. Perry (1794-1858) was an American Commodore, known primarily for his role in opening Japan to the West through the signing of the Treaty of Kanagawa in 1854. Born in Newport, Rhode Island, Perry was the son of Senator Timothy and Martha (née Mason) Perry. He grew up in Warren, Rhode Island, and pursued a career in the Navy after graduating from the United States Naval Academy in 1814.

Perry's naval career spanned over four decades, and he earned distinction as a sailor, warrior, and diplomat. During the War of 1812, Perry played a vital role in the successful defense of Washington, D.C., and later participated in several important campaigns in the Mediterranean, the Caribbean, and along the Pacific coast of the Americas.

In 1842, Perry was appointed as the Commander-in-Chief of the United States Pacific Squadron, where he undertook a four-year expedition to the Far East. This journey, which came to be known as the "Morrison Expedition," allowed him to explore the Hawaiian Islands, the coast of Alaska, and parts of Asia, including China and Japan. Perry's experiences in Asia inspired him to seek opportunities to expand U.S. influence in the region.

Perry returned to the United States in 1846 and was appointed as a Commodore, the highest rank in the Navy, in 1852. His primary objective was to accomplish a diplomatic mission in Japan, which had remained isolated from the Western world for over two centuries, a policy known as Sakoku. Perry's objective was to force Japan to open its doors to foreign trade, a policy which would greatly impact the course of East Asian history.

In 1853, Perry led a small fleet of warships, called the Black Ships, to Japan, landing at Uraga Harbor near Edo (now Tokyo) and demanding that the Japanese government negotiate trade terms with the United States. Initially, Japan's leaders rejected Perry's demands, but after Perry threatened to use military force if necessary, the Japanese decided to send a delegation to the United States in an effort to establish diplomatic relations.
